description.narrative: Governance institutions strengthened, ensuring gender equality, public service delivery and human rights for all by 2012.

description.narrative: This project provides two pronged support - 1) economic development activities for women in 4 target districts and 2) UN support to the national development plan Special efforts will be made towards promoting employment opportunities for women.
Strengthening existing businesses, especially at the small and medium scale level, and provide skills training to entrepreneurs.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration
Support to analysis and preparation for the NDP Increased number of economic activities in the 4 target districts led by women

comment.narrative: No coordinated support from the UN for the National Development Plan UN Programme of support to Women does not include a linkage to economic empowerment

policy, planning and administration
A robust inclusive finance sector that is accessible to all who require financial services and provides products that match client requirements

comment.narrative: Weak financial sector especially micro finance sector, with limited reach to the low segment of the population due to lack of a national inclusive finace development policy, uncondicive regulatory framwork, limited capacity of technical and financial service provides and absence of an apex body coordinate to advocate for inclusive finance
- Project closure activities - Resource mobilization for follow-up project
Project financially closed. Pipeline project on Mobile money inclusive business ecosystems, supported by AFIM.

Other General Services - support to civil society
Production of Human Development Report; Capacity building for National Youth Council including civic and voter education for the youth and sensitization of the youth on governance issues.

comment.narrative: No systematically organized up-to-date information on the situation of youth and their participation in governance structures; low levels of participation of youth in governance issues

description.narrative: Building on previous collaborative work of the Government of Lesotho and UNDP/UNCDF in the area of decentralization, this project aims to accelerate progress and deepen decentralization in Lesotho.

This project main purpose is to promote decentralized service delivery for social and economic growth through the development of transparent funding mechanisms and by improving the accountability of local authorities.

capital of a political entity
seat of a first-order administrative division

seat of a first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Accountability - local government finance

1. Local development funding: -Mechanism for local development funding set up and functioning -No. of decentralizing ministries understand and adopt the principles of local development funding -Number of districts and community councils (or increase) supported through the local funding -% increase in resources flowing to local levels as proportion of total national development budget 2. Decentralization and accountability systems: -Existence of studies documenting current decentralizations and accountability systems and proposing more appropriate principles -Existence of new principles/model for decentralization developed and piloted -Adoption of formula-based system of inter-governmental transfers; Integrated financial management Information System (IFMIS) linking the central financial operations and the district councils through the district sub-accountancies 3. Capacities of line ministries -Number of line ministries supported in decentralization -% of functions effectively unpackaged at local level -% of staff transferred - Number of councils assisted in decentralization

comment.narrative: 1. Local development Funding: -Draft frame work for local development funding -Ministries have little understanding of the local development funding mechanism -Only three districts and three councils directly supported through local development funding -Lack of data on existing funds provided to local levels 2. Decentralization and accountability systems: -New principles not consistently developed or implemented (only three districts (Maseru, Berea and Thaba Tseka) are piloting new principles) -Lesotho Governments Integrated financial management Information System (IFMIS) operational in Maseru and with access from sub-accountancies. 3. Capacities of line ministries: -Only Ministry of Works has decentralized, Min. of Health decentralization ongoing -There is no effective unpacking of functions at local level -The staff of the Ministry of Works has been transferred -No councils assisted: There is no programme of assistance to councils to decentralize

description.narrative: The Integrated Development Project consists of four focus areas,m implemented a set of strategic, high-impact projects, on policy management, HIV/AIDS mainstreaming, and statistics and M&E.
Increased capacities of industry and commerce operators to provide decent employment opportunities, particularly for vulnerable people in manufacturing, trade and services industries
policy, planning and administration

Existence of an Investment Policy Existence of a Trade Policy Existence of the Mining and Minerals Policy, and Legal framework DB ranking, No of days taken to register a business- 9 days; No of people accessing OBFC services

comment.narrative: No investment and trade policies Mining Rights Act 1967, Mining and Minerals Act 2005, No mining policy DB ranking # 162 (out of 189 countries); No of days to register a business 40 days

- Draft Trade policy - Mining policy and related legal framework - Support to OBFC for automation of the external trade procedures (ASYCUDA) assessment. Continue to increase number of people accessing OBFC services, and Reduce number of days taken to register a business to 9 days - 200 women and youth trained in entrepreneurship and 25% of them accessing funds for establishment of own micro and small enterprises

- The background to the development of the Trade policy has been published, however, due to lack of funding resources, limited coordination capacities within the relevant government ministry, the policy has not been developed yet. - The Mining and Minerals Policy was adopted by the GoL. In collaboration with UNECA, the legal framework has also been developed and submitted for drafting of the law for Mining and Minerals extraction in Lesotho. - Assessment for ASYCUDA (Automated System for Customs Data management) completed, with support from UNCTAD. This will further enable systems interfacing for improved number of days taken to register a business. The World Bank DB indicators reports 29days in Lesotho, while OBFC takes 3 days to complete registration processes. At least 22, 000 being 40% more people are using the OBFC services. - 202 people (164 women and 38 men) were trained in entrepreneurship skills and helped to establish own small and micro enteprises.

description.narrative: National capacities of government, civil society and private sector increased to mainstream HIV/AIDs issues into national and local policies and strategies.
Health - policy, planning and administration
Existence of NAC, Existence of HIV maintreaming guidelines (per ministry), Improved Global Gender Gapr Ranking,

comment.narrative: No National AIDS COordinationg Body in place; Draft EIA regulations, Draft HIV and the Law report (Legal Environment Impact Assessment), Draft Public Sector HIV Mainatreaming Guidelines, Draft regulations for TRIPS,

- Support re-inauguration of NAC (National AIDS Commission), Support implementation of the Public Sector Mainstreaming guidelines, - Support private sector gender mainstreaming and equity initiatives - Advocacy on reduced stigma and discrimination associated with HIV and AIDS among the youth and Basotho communities

- NAC inaugurated, with revised NAC Act, Board of Directors and Strategic Plan, - The Government of Lesotho adopted the Public Sector HIV and AIDS mainstreaming guidelines and resuscitated a ministerial coordinating committee to oversee the process. - Issued a first report towards private sector gender equity initiatives, by showcasing women portraits on roles played by women in different private sector companies, especially in positions that were traditionally held by men. - Published a 'Take a Pledge" documentary to encourage reduced stigma and discrimination among youth and Basotho communities, and using You Tube and social media, encourage voices and advocacy against HIV and AIDS related stigma and discrimination

description.narrative: Bridge the information gap for statistics, and data by building capacities for collection, use and analysis by strengthening the national capacities for M&E and statistics.
Existence of the MDG reports, Post 2015 agenda Annual research reports Statistical reports

comment.narrative: A draft M&E framework for NSDP MDG Report 2008 MDG Acceleration Framework (MAF)

- Publish the NHDR 2014/15 - Publish MDG 2015 Status Report - Post 2015 consultations and SDGs mobilization - Analysis and publish the Economic Census and Business register report - 4 issues of the Quarterly Socio Economic Policy review publication - Design and development of the project on sustainable data and statistics

- NHDR finalized. The report will be published in Q1 of 2016. - Issued the high level summary report on the status of the MDG 2015. The full report will be published in 2016. - SDG mobilization: o A multi-stakeholder forum for about 60 representatives for government, civil society and private sector on the SDGs processes and domestication of targets o 400 youth trained on SDGs and processes for effective participation and engagement - The Economic Census and Business register report published

capital of a political entity
Existence of core values for the civil service. Level of capacity of the Public Service Commission. Level of capacity of the Lesotho Institute for Public Administration & Managemen (LIPAM)

comment.narrative: Politicised civil service, absence of core shared values. Weak institutional capacities of to provide direction, training and support through LIPAM or the Public Service Commission
Target: 50% completion of Performance Agreement signed by all ministries
24 out of the 26 ministries have signed performance contracts

description.narrative: Development of cornerstone public policies and institutional capacities to accelarate Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) progress.
Development of cornerstone public policies and institutional capacities to accelarate Sustainable Energy for All (SE4A) progress
Energy - power generation

This LDCF - financed project will contribute to overcoming these barriers through strengthening institutional and technical capacities of government institutions to plan for and implement adaptation using an ecosystem management approach

Increased technical capacity of the Ministry of Forestry, Range and Soil Conservation, and relevant departments to apply up to date climate science for the management of evolving risks and uncertainty linked to climate change
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
The use of climate-driven vulnerabilities and cost-effective planning to inform the implementation of the Land Rehabilitation Programme.

comment.narrative: Climate change risks are not integrated into the Land Rehabilitation Programme. Target sites are chosen on an ad hoc basis. Rehabilitation and management measures are not tailored to specific ecosystems

The PMU is established and fully staffed and is functional The Terms of Reference are developed and the following specialists are recruited, CTA, GIS and Socio economic specialists to conduct vulnerability assessments at the Project sites
Project management Unit established Vulnerability assessments carried out

description.narrative: The objective of the Project is to support and promote the building of a conducive environment ahead of, during and after the early elections in 2015.
Organization and management of elections enhanced
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections
Level of acceptance of voter list by political parties and Percentage of observers clearing the elections as credible and accepted

comment.narrative: Low acceptance of election results, mostly challenged.
High level of acceptance of election results

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) held free, fair, credible and transparent National Assembly Elections in February 2015 as confirmed by all local and international observer missions. The project focused on the key areas of voter education, public outreach, training, logistics and coordination of observer initiatives.

comment.narrative: Institutional capacity gaps in IT, Logistics, Public Outreach and Observer Coordination
High level of acceptance of IEC capacity to run 2015 elections.
Action plan for post-elections Capacity building operational.
